elements.content: On the basis of the same reaction starting materials, microporous to mesoporous Mn­(II)-tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research) with different interpenetration structures have been obtained by applying different solvents and reaction temperatures. FIR-34 is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from small dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs), while FIR-35 based on large Mn5 SBUs is a non-interpenetrating framework with (3,8)-connected tfz-d network. Both of them have low porosity. However, the other non-interpenetrating framework (FIR-36) with large mesopores is built by rod-shaped Mn­(II)-carboxylate SBUs. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g–1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g–1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

FIR-34 is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from small dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs), while FIR-35 based on large Mn5 SBUs is a non-interpenetrating framework with (3,8)-connected tfz-d network. Both of them have low porosity. However, the other non-interpenetrating framework (FIR-36) with large mesopores is built by rod-shaped Mn(II)-carboxylate SBUs. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2⋅g-1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3⋅g-1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

elements.content: Three microporous and mesoporous Mn­(II)-tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) have been obtained through effective interpenetration control. Different solvent systems and reaction temperatures determine the interpenetration of a MOF structure. FIR-36 with non-interpenetrating structure has Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g−1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g−1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Introduction

Interpenetration in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is a common phenomenon, especially for large size organic linkers. For example, Yaghi et al. reported famous MOF-177 built by 1,3,5-tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene ligand. Lin and co-workers have reported a 2-fold interpenetrating porous MOF constructed from methanetetra­(biphenyl-p-carboxylic acid). In addition, as a long trigonal bridging ligand, tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine (H3TPA) has also been used to synthesize many interpenetrated MOFs by our group, such as 2-fold interpenetrating FIR-1, FIR-3, FIR-7, FIR-17, and 8-fold interpenetrating FIR-12, FIR-28, and so on. The use of large size linkers in attempt to synthesize MOFs with expected large pores is generally a very challenging task. Although interpenetration usually makes MOFs robust, it negatively affects the porosity of open frameworks by reducing the size of open pores. Up to now, there are several routes reported to realize interpenetration control in MOFs: (1) reaction temperature or concentration control, (2) template-directed control, (3) ligand design/modification-induced control, (4) coordinated or uncoordinated solvent removal/addition-triggered control, and (5) layer-by-layer assembly. The first three strategies are the most common and have been demonstrated to work well by different research groups or in various MOFs, but two strategies used at the same time are reported rarely.

Introduction

Interpenetration in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is a common phenomenon, especially for large size organic linkers. For example, Yaghi et al. reported famous MOF-177 built by 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene ligand. Lin and co-workers have reported a 2-fold interpenetrating porous MOF constructed from methanetetra(biphenyl-p-carboxylic acid). In addition, as a long trigonal bridging ligand, tris((4-carboxyl)phenylduryl)amine (H3TPA) has also been used to synthesize many interpenetrated MOFs by our group, such as 2-fold interpenetrating FIR-1, FIR-3, FIR-7, FIR-17, and 8-fold interpenetrating FIR-12, FIR-28, and so on. The use of large size linkers in attempt to synthesize MOFs with expected large pores is generally a very challenging task. Although interpenetration usually makes MOFs robust, it negatively affects the porosity of open frameworks by reducing the size of open pores. Up to now, there are several routes reported to realize interpenetration control in MOFs: (1) reaction temperature or concentration control, (2) template-directed control, (3) ligand design/modification-induced control, (4) coordinated or uncoordinated solvent removal/addition-triggered control, and (5) layer-by-layer assembly. elements.content: In this work, by using different solvents and controlling the reaction temperature, microporous to mesoporous Mn­(II)-TPA frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) have been synthesized. Compound FIR-34, namely, [Mn­(HTPA)­(DMF)2]­·(H2O) (DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs). Compound FIR-35, namely, [Mn5(HTPA)2­(TPA)2­(e-urea)6]­·6­(e-urea)­·2­(H2O) (e-urea = ethyleneurea), is a non-interpenetrating framework based on Mn5 SBUs and is described as a (3,8)-connected tfz-d net. Unfortunately, both compounds have low porosity. Interestingly, compound FIR-36, namely, [Mn3(TPA)2(H2O)­(DMI)2]­·7­(MeCN)­·9­(DMI) (DMI = 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone; MeCN = acetonitrile), is also a non-interpenetrating framework built by rod-shaped Mn­(II)-carboxylate SBUs, but it possesses large mesopores. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g–1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g–1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The purity of all gases is 99.999%. All syntheses were carried out in a 20 mL vial under autogenous pressure. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analysis (EA; C, H, and N) was carried out on a Vario Micro E III analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer at room temperature with a step size of 0.05°. Gas adsorption measurement was performed in the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The purity of all gases is 99.999%. All syntheses were carried out in a 20 mL vial under autogenous pressure. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analysis (EA; C, H, and N) was carried out on a Vario Micro E III analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer at room temperature with a step size of 0.05°. Gas adsorption measurement was performed in the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System.

elements.content: A total of 60 mg of H3TPA (0.1 mmol) and 40 mg of MnCl2 ·4H2O (0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:1:1, v/v) mixed solvents, which were placed in a small vial. The solution was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block-shaped crystals were formed and collected by filtration and washed with DMF several times (yield: 17% based on H3TPA). Elemental analysis for C45H41N3O9Mn, Calcd (%): C, 65.69; H, 5.02; N, 5.11. Found: C, 65.73; H, 4.97; N, 5.19.

elements.content: A total of 60 mg of H3TPA (0.1 mmol) and 40 mg of MnCl2 ·4H2O (0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of DMI/MeCN (2:1, v/v) mixed solvents, which were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (20 mL). The solution was heated at 140 °C for 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow needle-shaped crystals were formed and collected by filtration and washed with DMI several times (yield: 65% based on H3TPA). Elemental analysis for C147H181N31O24Mn3, Calcd (%): C, 60.23; H, 6.22; N, 14.81. Found: C, 60.17; H, 6.31; N, 14.87.

elements.content: Compound FIR-34: space group Aba2, orthorhombic, a = 37.475(2) Å, b = 13.3270(12) Å, c = 15.9941(14) Å, α = β = γ = 90.00°, V = 7987.9(11) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 8, 6920 reflections measured, 3810 independent reflections (R int = 0.0409). The final R 1 value was 0.0625 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1612 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.087. Compound FIR-35: space group P1̅, triclinic, a = 13.0203(5) Å, b = 19.7760(7) Å, c = 20.8274(8) Å, α = 61.932(4)°, β = 73.268(3)°, γ = 80.162(3)°, V = 4527.8(3) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 1, 21075 reflections measured, 9683 independent reflections (R int = 0.0280). The final R 1 value was 0.0484 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1308 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.055. Compound FIR-36: space group P21/c, monoclinic, a = 10.1565(3) Å, b = 37.9051(7) Å, c = 41.2175(9) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 99.894(2)°, γ = 90.00°, V = 15632.0(6) Å3, T = 103(6) K, Z = 4, 31179 reflections measured, 16 679 independent reflections (R int = 0.0623). The final R 1 value was 0.1666 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.4080 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.040. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. CCDC 1509909–1509911 (FIR-34–36) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of MnCl2 ·4H2O and H3TPA in a mixture of DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:1:1, v/v) at 80 °C yielded compound FIR-34. Single-crystal XRD reveals that FIR-34 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Aba2. The asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Mn2+ ion, one HTPA2– ligand, two coordinated DMF molecules (except for O atom, other atoms of coordinated DMF molecule are squeezed by the PLATON program because of disorder) and one guest H2O molecule. As seen in a and S1, the Mn2+ ion is six-coordinated to four carboxyl O atoms from three distinct HTPA2– ligands at the equatorial position and two DMF O atoms at the axial position, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Herein, the incomplete deprotonated tricarboxylate ligand actually serves as a V-shape dicarboxylate linker (about 19 Å in length), which adopts the following coordination mode: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1-μ2)-μ3. A pair of Mn2+ ions are bridged by two −O–C–O– bridges to generate a dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] unit with Mn···Mn distance of 4.21 Å. Each dinuclear unit is connected by four HTPA2– ligands to generate a diamond network (a and S2). The diamondoid cage has a minimum edge distance of 24 Å and a maximum distance of 75 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of eight independent three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, generating an 8-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (b,c). The interpenetration can be classified as type Ia, Z = 8 (Zt = 8; Zn = 1). In addition, there is very weak hydrogen bonding interaction (C7–H7A···O6 with the length of 3.275 Å and the angle of 143.72°) between adjacent frameworks (Figure S3). The solvent-accessible volume of FIR-34 without coordinated DMF molecules and H2O guests is only 28.7% per unit cell calculated by PLATON. Apparently, larger bridged ligands usually facilitate interpenetrated phenomenon, especially to connect small-sized and low-nuclear SBU.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reaction of MnCl2 ⋅4H2O and H3TPA in a mixture of DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:1:1, v/v) at 80 °C yielded compound FIR-34. Single-crystal XRD reveals that FIR-34 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Aba2. The asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Mn2+ ion, one HTPA2- ligand, two coordinated DMF molecules (except for O atom, other atoms of coordinated DMF molecule are squeezed by the PLATON program because of disorder) and one guest H2O molecule. As seen in a and S1, the Mn2+ ion is six-coordinated to four carboxyl O atoms from three distinct HTPA2- ligands at the equatorial position and two DMF O atoms at the axial position, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Herein, the incomplete deprotonated tricarboxylate ligand actually serves as a V-shape dicarboxylate linker (about 19 Å in length), which adopts the following coordination mode: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1-μ2)-μ3. A pair of Mn2+ ions are bridged by two -O-C-O- bridges to generate a dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] unit with Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance of 4.21 Å. Each dinuclear unit is connected by four HTPA2- ligands to generate a diamond network (a and S2). The diamondoid cage has a minimum edge distance of 24 Å and a maximum distance of 75 Å. The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of eight independent three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, generating an 8-fold interpenetrating 3D structure (b,c). The interpenetration can be classified as type Ia, Z = 8 (Zt = 8; Zn = 1). In addition, there is very weak hydrogen bonding interaction (C7-H7A⋅⋅⋅O6 with the length of 3.275 Å and the angle of 143.72°) between adjacent frameworks (Figure S3). The solvent-accessible volume of FIR-34 without coordinated DMF molecules and H2O guests is only 28.7% per unit cell calculated by PLATON. Apparently, larger bridged ligands usually facilitate interpenetrated phenomenon, especially to connect small-sized and low-nuclear SBU.

elements.content: When changing the synthetic method of compound FIR-34 to a urothermal reaction (here we use e-urea as a solvent) and raising the reaction temperature to 120 °C, compound FIR-35 was synthesized. Compound FIR-35 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As shown in b and S4, the asymmetric unit contains two and a half Mn2+ atoms, one HTPA2– ligand, one TPA3– ligand, three coordinated e-urea molecules, three e-urea guests, and one H2O molecule squeezed by PLATON program. The Mn1 and Mn2 ions possess a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, while the Mn3 ion is five-coordinated, showing a highly distorted square-pyramidal coordination geometry. The Mn1 ion lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by four O atoms from four different ligands and two e-urea O atoms. The Mn2 ion is coordinated by five O atoms from five ligands and one e-urea O atom. The Mn3 ion is coordinated by three O atoms from three different ligands and two e-urea O atoms. In FIR-35, half of the ligands are not completely deprotonated, and there are two kinds of coordination modes: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 and (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ2-μ2)-μ6 (Figure S5). The Mn1 ion bridges to two neighboring Mn2 ions by two −O–C–O– bridges and a μ2-O atom from a e-urea molecule to afford a linear Mn3 cluster. The Mn3 cluster is bridged to two neighboring Mn3 ions by two −O–C–O– bridges and a μ2-O atom from one carboxylate group to give a linear Mn5 cluster. The Mn5 cluster unit is further connected by 3-connecting TPA3– ligands and 2-connecting HTPA2– ligands to construct a 3D framework (a). Considering the 2-connecting HTPA2– ligands, each Mn5 cluster unit acts as a eight-connected node, and the trigonal TPA3– ligand keeps its three-connectivity. The network of FIR-35 can thus be topologically represented as a (3,8)-connected tfz-d net with point symbol (43)2(46·618·84) (c). Thus, it can be seen that large-sized and high-nuclear SBU effectively avoids interpenetration. However, the total potential void volume of FIR-35 without guests is only 21.2%, because the coordinated e-urea molecules and the noncoordinated carboxylate group occupy in the channels, which limit the size of the pores and influence the properties, especially gas sorption. Therefore, how to avoid interpenetration and construct open framework with large pores is challenging and significant.

elements.content: Interestingly, when adopting a mixed solvothermal and urothermal method (here we select DMI/MeCN as mixed solvents) and continuing to raise the reaction temperature to 140 °C, compound FIR-36 was obtained. FIR-36 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The local coordination geometry around each Mn2+ center is depicted in a and S6. In the asymmetric unit, there are three independent Mn2+ ions, two TPA3– ligands, one coordinated H2O molecule, two coordinated DMI molecules, and seven MeCN and nine DMI guests (except for O atom, other atoms of coordinated DMI molecule as well as all the guests are squeezed by the PLATON program because of disorder). Mn1 ion is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from five TPA3– ligands and one DMI O atom, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Mn2 ion also adopts octahedral coordination geometry, but it is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from four different TPA3– ligands and one H2O O atom. The Mn3 ion is five-coordinated to four O atoms from four different TPA3– ligands and one DMI O atom. In FIR-36, all the ligands are complete deprotonated, and there are two kinds of coordination modes: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 and (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2-μ2)-(κ1-κ2-μ3)-μ7 (Figure S7). Interestingly, three independent Mn centers are bridged by the carboxylate groups from TPA3– ligands to form a linear Mn3 cluster. Each Mn3 cluster is further linked by one −O–C–O– bridge, giving rise to an infinite chain with the terminal DMI molecules extending outside (a). Each resulting chain is further linked by the TPA3– linkers along the b and c axis to five neighboring ones, thus generating a 3D open framework with 1D channels along the a axis (b). There are two types of channels, the pore dimensions are 8 × 20 Å2 and 22 × 30 Å2 without the coordinated solvent molecules, respectively. The void volume of FIR-36 without coordinated solvent molecules and guests is above 66.7% of the cell volume. Remarkably, FIR-36 is a non-interpenetrated framework and possesses large pores. Actually, in our previous work, the porous non-interpenetrated frameworks FIR-4 and FIR-5 are also constructed by rod-shaped metal-carboxylate SBUs. The rigidity of the rod-shaped SBUs effectively avoids interpenetration due to the intrinsic packing arrangement of such rods in the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, when adopting a mixed solvothermal and urothermal method (here we select DMI/MeCN as mixed solvents) and continuing to raise the reaction temperature to 140 °C, compound FIR-36 was obtained. FIR-36 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The local coordination geometry around each Mn2+ center is depicted in a and S6. In the asymmetric unit, there are three independent Mn2+ ions, two TPA3- ligands, one coordinated H2O molecule, two coordinated DMI molecules, and seven MeCN and nine DMI guests (except for O atom, other atoms of coordinated DMI molecule as well as all the guests are squeezed by the PLATON program because of disorder). Mn1 ion is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from five TPA3- ligands and one DMI O atom, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Mn2 ion also adopts octahedral coordination geometry, but it is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from four different TPA3- ligands and one H2O O atom. The Mn3 ion is five-coordinated to four O atoms from four different TPA3- ligands and one DMI O atom. The void volume of FIR-36 without coordinated solvent molecules and guests is above 66.7% of the cell volume. Remarkably, FIR-36 is a non-interpenetrated framework and possesses large pores. Actually, in our previous work, the porous non-interpenetrated frameworks FIR-4 and FIR-5 are also constructed by rod-shaped metal-carboxylate SBUs. The rigidity of the rod-shaped SBUs effectively avoids interpenetration due to the intrinsic packing arrangement of such rods in the crystal structure.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in N2 atomsphere to study the thermal stability of FIR-36. As shown in Figure S8, compound FIR-36 started to lose its MeCN guests and coordinated H2O molecules at 100 °C, followed by partial loss of its DMI guest molecules between 100 and 380 °C, with the weight losses of 10.38% and 35.08% (calculated 10.41% and 35.01%), respectively. Above 380 °C, FIR-36 started to lose its coordinated DMI molecules, with the weight losses of 7.73% (calculated 7.78%). In the end, it started to lose its ligands TPA3– as a result of thermal decomposition with the final residue unknown at 650 °C. Herein, because the high boiling point guest DMI is very difficult to activate, FIR-36 was immersed into low boiling point MeCN solvent. The TGA of exchanged sample FIR-36a shows that DMI guests can be completely exchanged with MeCN, except for the coordinated DMI molecules. For gas sorption study, FIR-36a was evacuated under a dynamic vacuum at 50 °C overnight to give a desolvated solid FIR-36a-ht. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of FIR-36a-ht shows sharp diffraction peaks similar to those of FIR-36 (Figure S9), indicating that the porous framework is largely maintained. On the other hand, peaks corresponding to the relative position show an apparent shift to higher angle; this result clearly indicates shrinking or distortion of the framework, which may be attributable to the rotation of the −O–C–O– bridge in the metal-carboxylate chain, which decreases the pore size.

In the end, it started to lose its ligands TPA3- as a result of thermal decomposition with the final residue unknown at 650 °C. Herein, because the high boiling point guest DMI is very difficult to activate, FIR-36 was immersed into low boiling point MeCN solvent. The TGA of exchanged sample FIR-36a shows that DMI guests can be completely exchanged with MeCN, except for the coordinated DMI molecules. elements.content: The porosity of desolvated FIR-36a-ht was established by reversible N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which shows that it exhibits a typical type-I sorption behavior and N2 uptake of ∼188.5 cm3·g–1 at 1 bar (). Its BET and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 595.5 m2·g–1 and 825.3 m2·g–1, respectively. The measured pore volume from the N2 sorption is only 0.292 cm3·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.98. These pore parameters are greatly lower than those estimated from the single crystal structure, which further demonstrates shrinking or distortion of the framework after removal of guests. On the other hand, the coordinated DMI solvents are difficult to exchange and activate at relative low temperature, which occupy the channels and limit the pore size. Though the surface area of FIR-36a-ht is inferior, the H2 uptake capacity reaches 134.5 cm3·g–1 (1.20 wt %) at 77 K and 1 bar, a value surpassing that of FIR-7a-ht (126.1 cm3·g–1, 1.13 wt %) reported earlier and comparable to those of recently reported MOFs at the same condition. At zero coverage, the H2 adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of FIR-36a-ht calculated by the virial equation from the adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K is 7.4 kJ·mol–1.

elements.content: In summary, we reported here three microporous and mesoporous Mn­(II)-tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) through effective interpenetration control. Different solvent systems and reaction temperatures may determine the interpenetration of a MOF structure. These results demonstrated that the occurrence of interpenetration in MOF with large size linkers is controllable.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we reported here three microporous and mesoporous Mn(II)-tris((4-carboxyl)phenylduryl)amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) through effective interpenetration control. Different solvent systems and reaction temperatures may determine the interpenetration of a MOF structure. These results demonstrated that the occurrence of interpenetration in MOF with large size linkers is controllable.

A total of 60 mg of H3TPA (0.1 mmol) and 40 mg of MnCl2 ·4H2O (0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:1:1, v/v) mixed solvents, which were placed in a small vial. The solution was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block-shaped crystals were formed and collected by filtration and washed with DMF several times (yield: 17% based on H3TPA). Elemental analysis for C45H41N3O9Mn, Calcd (%): C, 65.69; H, 5.02; N, 5.11. Found: C, 65.73; H, 4.97; N, 5.19.

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>5</sub>(HTPA)<sub>2</sub>­(TPA)<sub>2</sub>­(e-urea)<sub>6</sub>]­·6­(e-urea)­·2­(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>FIR-35</bold>)

A total of 60 mg of H3TPA (0.1 mmol), 40 mg of MnCl2 ·4H2O (0.2 mmol) and 6 g of e-urea (70 mmol) were placed in a small vial. The mixture was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block-shaped crystals were formed and collected by filtration and washed with DMF several times (yield: 34% based on H3TPA). Elemental analysis for C192H174N28O38Mn5, Calcd (%): C, 61.39; H, 4.67; N, 10.44. Found: C, 61.31; H, 4.73; N, 10.42.

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>3</sub>(TPA)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(DMI)<sub>2</sub>]­·7­(MeCN)­·9­(DMI) (<bold>FIR-36</bold>)

A total of 60 mg of H3TPA (0.1 mmol) and 40 mg of MnCl2 ·4H2O (0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of DMI/MeCN (2:1, v/v) mixed solvents, which were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (20 mL). The solution was heated at 140 °C for 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow needle-shaped crystals were formed and collected by filtration and washed with DMI several times (yield: 65% based on H3TPA). Elemental analysis for C147H181N31O24Mn3, Calcd (%): C, 60.23; H, 6.22; N, 14.81. Found: C, 60.17; H, 6.31; N, 14.87.

cln_elements.content:
On the basis of the same reaction starting materials, microporous to mesoporous Mn­(II)-tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research) with different interpenetration structures have been obtained by applying different solvents and reaction temperatures. FIR-34 is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from small dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs), while FIR-35 based on large Mn5 SBUs is a non-interpenetrating framework with (3,8)-connected tfz-d network. Both of them have low porosity. However, the other non-interpenetrating framework (FIR-36) with large mesopores is built by rod-shaped Mn­(II)-carboxylate SBUs. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g–1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g–1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

Three microporous and mesoporous Mn­(II)-tris­((4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl)­amine frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) have been obtained through effective interpenetration control. Different solvent systems and reaction temperatures determine the interpenetration of a MOF structure. FIR-36 with non-interpenetrating structure has Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g−1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g−1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

In this work, by using different solvents and controlling the reaction temperature, microporous to mesoporous Mn­(II)-TPA frameworks (FIR-34 to FIR-36) have been synthesized. Compound FIR-34, namely, [Mn­(HTPA)­(DMF)2]­·(H2O) (DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs). Compound FIR-35, namely, [Mn5(HTPA)2­(TPA)2­(e-urea)6]­·6­(e-urea)­·2­(H2O) (e-urea = ethyleneurea), is a non-interpenetrating framework based on Mn5 SBUs and is described as a (3,8)-connected tfz-d net. Unfortunately, both compounds have low porosity. Interestingly, compound FIR-36, namely, [Mn3(TPA)2(H2O)­(DMI)2]­·7­(MeCN)­·9­(DMI) (DMI = 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone; MeCN = acetonitrile), is also a non-interpenetrating framework built by rod-shaped Mn­(II)-carboxylate SBUs, but it possesses large mesopores. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2·g–1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3·g–1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

Crystal Data

Compound FIR-34: space group Aba2, orthorhombic, a = 37.475(2) Å, b = 13.3270(12) Å, c = 15.9941(14) Å, α = β = γ = 90.00°, V = 7987.9(11) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 8, 6920 reflections measured, 3810 independent reflections (R int = 0.0409). The final R 1 value was 0.0625 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1612 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.087. Compound FIR-35: space group P1̅, triclinic, a = 13.0203(5) Å, b = 19.7760(7) Å, c = 20.8274(8) Å, α = 61.932(4)°, β = 73.268(3)°, γ = 80.162(3)°, V = 4527.8(3) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 1, 21075 reflections measured, 9683 independent reflections (R int = 0.0280). The final R 1 value was 0.0484 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1308 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.055. Compound FIR-36: space group P21/c, monoclinic, a = 10.1565(3) Å, b = 37.9051(7) Å, c = 41.2175(9) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 99.894(2)°, γ = 90.00°, V = 15632.0(6) Å3, T = 103(6) K, Z = 4, 31179 reflections measured, 16 679 independent reflections (R int = 0.0623). The final R 1 value was 0.1666 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.4080 (I > 2σ­(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.040. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. CCDC 1509909–1509911 (FIR-34–36) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

Interestingly, when adopting a mixed solvothermal and urothermal method (here we select DMI/MeCN as mixed solvents) and continuing to raise the reaction temperature to 140 °C, compound FIR-36 was obtained. FIR-36 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The local coordination geometry around each Mn2+ center is depicted in a and S6. Mn1 ion is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from five TPA3– ligands and one DMI O atom, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Mn2 ion also adopts octahedral coordination geometry, but it is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from four different TPA3– ligands and one H2O O atom. The Mn3 ion is five-coordinated to four O atoms from four different TPA3– ligands and one DMI O atom. In FIR-36, all the ligands are complete deprotonated, and there are two kinds of coordination modes: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 and (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2-μ2)-(κ1-κ2-μ3)-μ7 (Figure S7). Interestingly, three independent Mn centers are bridged by the carboxylate groups from TPA3– ligands to form a linear Mn3 cluster. Each Mn3 cluster is further linked by one −O–C–O– bridge, giving rise to an infinite chain with the terminal DMI molecules extending outside (a). Each resulting chain is further linked by the TPA3– linkers along the b and c axis to five neighboring ones, thus generating a 3D open framework with 1D channels along the a axis (b). There are two types of channels, the pore dimensions are 8 × 20 Å2 and 22 × 30 Å2 without the coordinated solvent molecules, respectively. The void volume of FIR-36 without coordinated solvent molecules and guests is above 66.7% of the cell volume. Remarkably, FIR-36 is a non-interpenetrated framework and possesses large pores. Actually, in our previous work, the porous non-interpenetrated frameworks FIR-4 and FIR-5 are also constructed by rod-shaped metal-carboxylate SBUs. The rigidity of the rod-shaped SBUs effectively avoids interpenetration due to the intrinsic packing arrangement of such rods in the crystal structure.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in N2 atomsphere to study the thermal stability of FIR-36. As shown in Figure S8, compound FIR-36 started to lose its MeCN guests and coordinated H2O molecules at 100 °C, followed by partial loss of its DMI guest molecules between 100 and 380 °C, with the weight losses of 10.38% and 35.08% (calculated 10.41% and 35.01%), respectively. Above 380 °C, FIR-36 started to lose its coordinated DMI molecules, with the weight losses of 7.73% (calculated 7.78%). In the end, it started to lose its ligands TPA3– as a result of thermal decomposition with the final residue unknown at 650 °C. The TGA of exchanged sample FIR-36a shows that DMI guests can be completely exchanged with MeCN, except for the coordinated DMI molecules. For gas sorption study, FIR-36a was evacuated under a dynamic vacuum at 50 °C overnight to give a desolvated solid FIR-36a-ht. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of FIR-36a-ht shows sharp diffraction peaks similar to those of FIR-36 (Figure S9), indicating that the porous framework is largely maintained. On the other hand, peaks corresponding to the relative position show an apparent shift to higher angle; this result clearly indicates shrinking or distortion of the framework, which may be attributable to the rotation of the −O–C–O– bridge in the metal-carboxylate chain, which decreases the pore size.

Compound FIR-34, namely, [Mn(HTPA)(DMF)2]⋅(H2O) (DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide), is an 8-fold interpenetrating dia framework constructed from dinuclear [Mn2(COO)4] secondary building units (SBUs). Compound FIR-35, namely, [Mn5(HTPA)2(TPA)2(e-urea)6]⋅6(e-urea)⋅2(H2O) (e-urea = ethyleneurea), is a non-interpenetrating framework based on Mn5 SBUs and is described as a (3,8)-connected tfz-d net. Unfortunately, both compounds have low porosity. Interestingly, compound FIR-36, namely, [Mn3(TPA)2(H2O)(DMI)2]⋅7(MeCN)⋅9(DMI) (DMI = 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone; MeCN = acetonitrile), is also a non-interpenetrating framework built by rod-shaped Mn(II)-carboxylate SBUs, but it possesses large mesopores. Gas sorption measurements for FIR-36 give a Langmuir surface area of 825.3 m2⋅g-1 and a H2 uptake of 134.5 cm3⋅g-1 at 77 K and 1 bar.

Crystal Data

Compound FIR-34: space group Aba2, orthorhombic, a = 37.475(2) Å, b = 13.3270(12) Å, c = 15.9941(14) Å, α = β = γ = 90.00°, V = 7987.9(11) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 8, 6920 reflections measured, 3810 independent reflections (R int = 0.0409). The final R 1 value was 0.0625 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1612 (I > 2σ(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.087. Compound FIR-35: space group P1̅, triclinic, a = 13.0203(5) Å, b = 19.7760(7) Å, c = 20.8274(8) Å, α = 61.932(4)°, β = 73.268(3)°, γ = 80.162(3)°, V = 4527.8(3) Å3, T = 293(2) K, Z = 1, 21075 reflections measured, 9683 independent reflections (R int = 0.0280). The final R 1 value was 0.0484 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1308 (I > 2σ(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.055. Compound FIR-36: space group P21/c, monoclinic, a = 10.1565(3) Å, b = 37.9051(7) Å, c = 41.2175(9) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 99.894(2)°, γ = 90.00°, V = 15632.0(6) Å3, T = 103(6) K, Z = 4, 31179 reflections measured, 16679 independent reflections (R int = 0.0623). The final R 1 value was 0.1666 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.4080 (I > 2σ(I)). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.040. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. CCDC 1509909-1509911 (FIR-34-36) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

Interestingly, when adopting a mixed solvothermal and urothermal method (here we select DMI/MeCN as mixed solvents) and continuing to raise the reaction temperature to 140 °C, compound FIR-36 was obtained. FIR-36 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The local coordination geometry around each Mn2+ center is depicted in a and S6. In the asymmetric unit, there are three independent Mn2+ ions, two TPA3- ligands, one coordinated H2O molecule, two coordinated DMI molecules, and seven MeCN and nine DMI guests (except for O atom, other atoms of coordinated DMI molecule as well as all the guests are squeezed by the PLATON program because of disorder). Mn1 ion is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from five TPA3- ligands and one DMI O atom, showing distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Mn2 ion also adopts octahedral coordination geometry, but it is coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from four different TPA3- ligands and one H2O O atom. The Mn3 ion is five-coordinated to four O atoms from four different TPA3- ligands and one DMI O atom. In FIR-36, all the ligands are complete deprotonated, and there are two kinds of coordination modes: (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 and (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2-μ2)-(κ1-κ2-μ3)-μ7 (Figure S7). Interestingly, three independent Mn centers are bridged by the carboxylate groups from TPA3- ligands to form a linear Mn3 cluster. Each Mn3 cluster is further linked by one -O-C-O- bridge, giving rise to an infinite chain with the terminal DMI molecules extending outside (a). Each resulting chain is further linked by the TPA3- linkers along the b and c axis to five neighboring ones, thus generating a 3D open framework with 1D channels along the a axis (b). There are two types of channels, the pore dimensions are 8 × 20 Å2 and 22 × 30 Å2 without the coordinated solvent molecules, respectively. The void volume of FIR-36 without coordinated solvent molecules and guests is above 66.7% of the cell volume. Remarkably, FIR-36 is a non-interpenetrated framework and possesses large pores. Actually, in our previous work, the porous non-interpenetrated frameworks FIR-4 and FIR-5 are also constructed by rod-shaped metal-carboxylate SBUs. The rigidity of the rod-shaped SBUs effectively avoids interpenetration due to the intrinsic packing arrangement of such rods in the crystal structure. 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in N2 atomsphere to study the thermal stability of FIR-36. As shown in Figure S8, compound FIR-36 started to lose its MeCN guests and coordinated H2O molecules at 100 °C, followed by partial loss of its DMI guest molecules between 100 and 380 °C, with the weight losses of 10.38% and 35.08% (calculated 10.41% and 35.01%), respectively. Above 380 °C, FIR-36 started to lose its coordinated DMI molecules, with the weight losses of 7.73% (calculated 7.78%). In the end, it started to lose its ligands TPA3- as a result of thermal decomposition with the final residue unknown at 650 °C. Herein, because the high boiling point guest DMI is very difficult to activate, FIR-36 was immersed into low boiling point MeCN solvent. The TGA of exchanged sample FIR-36a shows that DMI guests can be completely exchanged with MeCN, except for the coordinated DMI molecules. For gas sorption study, FIR-36a was evacuated under a dynamic vacuum at 50 °C overnight to give a desolvated solid FIR-36a-ht. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of FIR-36a-ht shows sharp diffraction peaks similar to those of FIR-36 (Figure S9), indicating that the porous framework is largely maintained. On the other hand, peaks corresponding to the relative position show an apparent shift to higher angle; this result clearly indicates shrinking or distortion of the framework, which may be attributable to the rotation of the -O-C-O- bridge in the metal-carboxylate chain, which decreases the pore size.

porosity.condition: without coordinated solvent molecules and guests

decomposition temperature.type: loss of MeCN guests and coordinated H2O molecules
partial loss of DMI guest molecules
loss of ligands TPA3- due to thermal decomposition

cln_elements.content: The porosity of desolvated FIR-36a-ht was established by reversible N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which shows that it exhibits a typical type-I sorption behavior and N2 uptake of ∼188.5 cm3·g–1 at 1 bar (). Its BET and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 595.5 m2·g–1 and 825.3 m2·g–1, respectively. The measured pore volume from the N2 sorption is only 0.292 cm3·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.98. These pore parameters are greatly lower than those estimated from the single crystal structure, which further demonstrates shrinking or distortion of the framework after removal of guests. On the other hand, the coordinated DMI solvents are difficult to exchange and activate at relative low temperature, which occupy the channels and limit the pore size. Though the surface area of FIR-36a-ht is inferior, the H2 uptake capacity reaches 134.5 cm3·g–1 (1.20 wt %) at 77 K and 1 bar, a value surpassing that of FIR-7a-ht (126.1 cm3·g–1, 1.13 wt %) reported earlier and comparable to those of recently reported MOFs at the same condition. At zero coverage, the H2 adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of FIR-36a-ht calculated by the virial equation from the adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K is 7.4 kJ·mol–1.
